head.title: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records;No More Lies

hedline.hl1: It's Time for Openness in Adoption Records;No More Lies

block.p: The controversy over access to adoption records (front page, March 18) is faced not just by the people of Tennessee but internationally.
The controversy over access to adoption records (front page, March 18) is faced not just by the people of Tennessee but internationally.

In Ireland it has come to light that from the 1950's to possibly as late as the 1970's, as many as 2,000 Irish-born babies were placed with adoptive families in the United States. Ireland's National Archives has information on these placements, each file containing enough information to link adoptee with birth mother.

By practice rather than law, such records are closed. However, such has been the furor surrounding these files that the Foreign Minister, Dick Spring, has announced plans to introduce some mechanism to allow release of information and contact between those who desire it.
Voluntary organizations working in the adoption field in Ireland agree that tracing and contact is a healing process for those concerned.

There will always be those who do not wish contact, whether birth mother or adoptee. The needs of such people can be accommodated without denying the rights of those who wish to trace, or those who are not averse to being traced.
We live in a modern, open society. It is time to do away with the lies, mistrust and secrecy of a bygone era and to replace those values with openness, healing and enlightenment.
ANTON SWEENEY Secretary, Adoption Action Dublin, March 19, 1996
